comments.body:
not sure if it belongs here or somewhere else but you need more tests for numeric operations. Specifically:
- timedeltaindex + timedelta
- timedeltaindex - timedelta
- timedeltaindex \* timedelta (should raise)
- timedeltaindex / timedelta (float64index?)
- timedeltaindex + datetime (datetimeindex?)
- timedeltaindex - datetime (raises)

its amazing how many combination their are for addition ops (and the reverse ops are not automatically implemented):

`tdi=timedeltaindex, dti=datetimeindex, td=timedelta,dt=datetime`

```
tdi + td
td + tdi
tdi + dt
dt + tdi
td + dt
dt + td
tdi + dti
dti + tdi
```
note:these are all in tseries/test_base.py
maybe tests with tz-aware index (result should be the same w.r.t. to the tz)
need a test for passing invalid `method` (put in Base so its tested for all Index classes). Though since you override the checking, might be necessary to have some individual tests for this.

move this to the `Base` class which tests for all sub-classes

ahh, you know what the function above it is not testing much `test_str` (that's what I was looking at). should be iterating over the `self.indices` rather than using `.create_index()`.

I am not fully following the logic of the test set up.
- on the one hand, you have the `self.indices` -> so iterating over these will run this test for all the different index types
- but `create_index` is also redefined in each subclass of `Base`, so in this way the test will also be run for the different index types

So it seems two ways to achieve a bit the same?
`.indices` has much more to test (and is customizable per sub-class), while `.create_index` is a single plain vanilla one. For the generic tests using `.indices` provides more coverage.

@jreback I'm able to include `MultiIndex` testing in the `test_equals_op` function above

everything works the same way except for one wrinkle, when testing the "broadcast when comparing with a scalar" rule:

```
In [1]: import pandas as pd

In [2]: mi = pd.MultiIndex.from_tuples([(1, 2), (4, 5), (8, 9)])

In [3]: mi
Out[3]:
MultiIndex(levels=[[1, 4, 8], [2, 5, 9]],
           labels=[[0, 1, 2], [0, 1, 2]])

In [4]: mi[0]
Out[4]: (1, 2)

In [5]: mi == mi[0]
Out[5]: False
```

Note that instead of broadcasting it thinks that `mi[0]` i.e. `(1, 2)` is an array of length 2, and the comparison in that case defaults to comparing the underlying numpy arrays, and therefore it returns `False`

That's why for `MultiIndex` I'm skipping these asserts
Instead include multiindex and special case that test (u can just to an isinstance MultiIndex to detect) and put your comment from above there
sure sounds good, it's updated
